Description: Oblong scaraboid in glazed composition, probably mould-made; back in the shape of a couchant lion; underside bearing hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically.
Curator's comments: Scaraboid not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 64). Lion scaraboids belong to a common series produced at Naukratis (on the ‘Scarab Factory’ productions, see Webb forthcoming). Moulds to produce lion scaraboids were discovered in Naukratis: BM 1896,0610.16 and BM 1896,0610.17. Numerous couchant lion scaraboids were discovered in Naukratis (see for example the ones illustrated in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, nos. 50, 64, 69, 80, 92, 99, 104). This scaraboid belongs to a type widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and in South Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B152-160, see especially B153 for this piece). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it is possible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun-Ra (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). The lion shape of the scaraboid itself can be associated with solar deties. Lions were used to write the name of Ra during the Late Period, as the lion is a phonetic equivalent Rw (De Wit 1951, 138ff). De Wit, C. 1951, Le rôle et le sens du lion dans l’Egypte ancienne, Leiden. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
